creator: pieter.bloemendaal@spmtechnologies.com
text:
The doc page for the Ant echo task says: "As XML parsers are wont to do, the 
first newline in the text element has been included in the text. "
I think this should be rewritten, it does not seem to make sense.

creator: antoine@apache.org
text:
Would you like a sentence like :
"the newline following immediately the tag <echo> will be part of the output"
I do not know whether this behavior is defined by an official XML norm, or if it
is possible to develop a "legal" XML parser which would ignore this first
carriage return.

creator: pieter.bloemendaal@sap.com
text:
Hi,
Yes I think that (slightly rephrased):
"The newline immediately following the <echo> tag will be part of the output."
is much better.

creator: mbenson@apache.org
text: I'm still trying to figure out what part of the original wording lacks sense.

creator: antoine@apache.org
text:
This bit "As XML parsers are wont to do," is not understandable for me.
I guess this means something like "XML parser implementations consider the
newlines inside a tag to be part of the text content".

I suppose that phrase is a fairly obscure part of the English language.  Well, 
whatever fails to confuse people, then.  Perhaps the non-native reader reads 
that as "won't" missing its apostrophe, which indeed would make little sense.  
The word "wont" here might be replaced with "apt" or "likely".
creator: mbenson@apache.org
